text: "HFT" is a broad church. Are dark pools and front-running bad for all but the operators? Yes. Is the ability to algorithmically trade and provide a large amount of liquidity beneficial for more people than the operators? Yes. There's a spectrum between those - the benefit is in the eye of the viewer most times.

text: I think most successful betfair (manual) traders would automate if they could, and they would increase transaction volume if they could - does that mean manual trading == good and hft algotrading on the same strategy on the same market == bad?

text: A lot of what we do on Betfair can be thought of as liquidity provision. If my counterparties did not trade against me, their prices would be worse. I give them a better price, and make a little bit of cash each time as I have a superior pricing model.

text: I think where it gets darker is in financial markets where dark pools are front-running because the prices don't get worse if you remove them, so the whole purpose is just to give the operators inside information

text: Personally (as a fan of the horses), I don't like drone players because their dream outcome is likely a leading horse falling at the last, but I accept they can argue they're making the market more efficient, and their claim that if pictures weren't laggy it wouldn't be an issue. Pretty classic Shannon Information Theory in action, really.

text: Your buy and hold investor would not be able to function without someone willing to lay it to them. Someone has to provide that service. Having an exchange gives them a better price than being forced to use a bookmaker.

text: <@U01Q94VE1AB> has joined the channel

don't personally agree that HFT is net negative. transaction costs over the last 20yrs have fallen enormously, particularly for institutions. people often go on about the good old days with market makers, pits etc. even in the early 2000s you'd have institutions paying 25bps commission and facing maybe three times that in slippage, whereas its maybe a tenth of that.

text: Yeah these people who bang on about mindset and psychology are usually vacuous arseholes trying to sell you an ebook. If you are a manual trader then for sure some elementary common sense "psychology" can be useful. At the end of the day if you don't have some kind of edge that makes you profitable then psychology is meaningless. You can have the most positive mindset in the world and great self discipline but if you have no edge you will end up in the poorhouse regardless. But it's an easy e-book to write (by write I mean copy paste someone else's ebook) and sell to the gullible. In this way they also cover themselves when they sell you their "trading guide" or "course" as that way they can blame it all on YOUR mindset and discipline when you discover that their shitty methods don't work. This may sound overly cynical but the space is awash with such nonsense.

text: As for "pretty selfish game really if you think about it" <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> yes it is. If you win on betfair you are taking it from another betfair customer. As unpalatable as that seems at time, this is what has to happen to make profit in this game.

text: <@U01RME87V3J> has joined the channel

I don't think it's as black and white as that.

Suppose a market has a BATB price of 2.0. Mr Flumine User improves the price by offering 2.02. Mr Caan comes along and takes the best price.

If Mr Flumine User wasn't there, MC would have received odds of 2.0 vs 2.02. So he is better off with lots of Flumine users offering prices.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon

text: latency arb is bad for most market participants - unless there are mechanisms that protect the market maker, they'll be less confident about quoting a tighter spread due to fear of being picked off. Less tight spreads = higher transaction costs for everyone

text:
I find it a potentially interesting problem. In my case it's not really affecting me yet as i'm not pushing stakes hard at all. But more from the point of view if you have two separate strategies that want different prices from the same tick update I could view that many ways. I could be asking for a better price on one strategy, maybe i'd rather a lower price to improve matching, maybe increasing stakes of the lower priced strategy might take away a decent chunk from the latter.
I guess it still goes back to what you was saying, a unified strategy that could then be AB tested.

text: Yeah for my part I'd see that as a better solution. Really what you're talking about seems to be optimal execution pricing which can be fiendishly hard as you start to weigh up a number of variables. The only solution to that is data and for that I'd use some kind of randomisation. The way I deal with this myself is to estimate optimal execution (prices, stakes, number of bets) and then randomise all those things within reasonable parameters. Eventually (like a year later) I have enough data to meaningfully re-address my view on the optimums then I rinse and repeat.

text:
There’s no getting away from sports betting being a zero sum game. Net winners offset net losers and bookmakers and exchanges take their cut. You can argue that “providing liquidity” adds value to the system, but ultimately if you didn’t take the other side of the bet and win then no one would lose. So financially, winners are clearly not contributing to the system. 

In my opinion, the only way to frame the “non-zero” game argument is to say that value is created through the entertainment of gambling. Losers are happy to pay a premium for the excitement of placing a bet even though they lose in the long run (otherwise why would they continue), and winners are compensated for offering that service (for the financial risk and work of pricing up the bets). So it is a net positive system in my opinion. As for whether people should be allowed to gamble or how, or whether it’s rational to gamble if you’re a net loser, is a separate question.

elements.text:

You can argue that “providing liquidity” adds value to the system, but ultimately if you didn’t take the other side of the bet and win then no one would lose. So financially, winners are clearly not contributing to the system. 

In my opinion, the only way to frame the “non-zero” game argument is to say that value is created through the entertainment of gambling. Losers are happy to pay a premium for the excitement of placing a bet even though they lose in the long run (otherwise why would they continue), and winners are compensated for offering that service (for the financial risk and work of pricing up the bets). So it is a net positive system in my opinion. As for whether people should be allowed to gamble or how, or whether it’s rational to gamble if you’re a net loser, is a separate question.

text: For financial systems, there’s value in funding (loans and equity release) where commission / interest is made for providing the service and taking on the risk. Ultimately financial markets are for transacting risk, and you pay a premium to convert risk, or buy / sell risk. There’s utility for people who want to change whatever risk they own into higher or lower risk and they will pay to do that. However a large part of it is still zero sum like sports betting in my opinion.

elements.text: For financial systems, there’s value in funding (loans and equity release) where commission / interest is made for providing the service and taking on the risk. Ultimately financial markets are for transacting risk, and you pay a premium to convert risk, or buy / sell risk. There’s utility for people who want to change whatever risk they own into higher or lower risk and they will pay to do that. However a large part of it is still zero sum like sports betting in my opinion.

text: I had the same thought as James. You dont offer a better price because you want to increase liquidity, but rather because you have a higher chance to get matched. Basically you are offering "less financial damage" in order to apply this damage to more people, but with the goal to maximize overall financial dmg on the other end, as that is your win. Still i wouldnt say its that terrible, because i also agree with James that its not actually zero - sum. There are ppl who just want to enjoy their game and like the extra kick that a few bugs on their team/horse adds. Randomness can be fun, that is why its implemented in so many games. And in that regard, a competetive market is actually a good thing, as casual better can happily place a bet and know that he is actually getting a good price, with only a very slight -ev, maybe a few cents per bet. That price may be easily outweighted by the extra fun he can get out of his game. Unlike bookmakers, where you are just getting screwed over :smile:
